title: Risk and protective factors: building safe relationships in childhood
excerpt: What increases risk, what protects, and how to foster caring environments.
intro: Understanding risk and protective factors helps prevent child maltreatment and promote wellbeing. This is not about blame, but about identifying conditions that raise or lower risk to act prudently and with care.
In Latino homes, strengthening networks, everyday habits and community resources is key to building safe, stable relationships.
keyIdeas: Risk and protection operate across multiple levels: individual, relationship/family, community and society.
Some factors increase vulnerability (economic stress, isolation, lack of support); others reduce it (support networks, sensitive parenting, access to services).
Prevention means increasing what protects and reducing what puts at risk, with coordinated actions at home and in the community.

sections.title: Prevention and safe relationships
sections.body: Safe relationships are built with presence, clear limits and consistent emotional support. Prevention is everyday work: listening, respectful monitoring and modeling care reduce exposure to risks.

signals: High economic stress and limited social support
Caregiver mental health or substance use challenges
Community environments with violence and few safe activities
actions: Positive bonds and active caregiver presence
Sensitive parenting and clear rules with monitoring
Support networks: extended family, school, neighbors and mentors
Access to services: health, mental health, after-school programs and economic help
closure: Every family and community can add protection by strengthening networks, habits and access to resources. Small, sustained steps create safer, more hopeful environments.
